questions.question: What does DNS stand for?
questions.explanation: DNS: translates names to addresses. Purpose: web accessibility. Servers: distributed globally. Caching: improves performance. Security: DNSSEC adds validation. Examples: 8.8.8.8 public resolver.

questions.question: What does VPN stand for?
questions.explanation: VPN: secure network tunnel. Purpose: privacy, security. Implementation: encryption protocols. Speed: adds latency typically. Uses: public WiFi safety. Providers: commercial services available.

questions.question: What does FTP stand for?
questions.explanation: FTP: file transfer standard. Security: deprecated for sensitive data. Modern: SFTP, FTPS alternatives. Port: 21 traditional. Speed: slower than modern protocols. Purpose: website file management.

questions.question: What does HTTP stand for?
questions.explanation: HTTP: web page transfer protocol. Port: 80 standard. Security: no encryption (use HTTPS). Methods: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE. Stateless: each request independent. Standards: RFC 7231 defines.

questions.question: What does HTTPS stand for?
questions.explanation: HTTPS: encrypted HTTP version. Security: SSL/TLS encryption. Port: 443 standard. Certificates: cryptographic validation. Adoption: becoming mandatory. Importance: financial, personal data protection.

questions.question: What does SMTP stand for?
questions.explanation: SMTP: email sending protocol. Port: 25, 587, 465 used. Function: relays messages. Authentication: credentials typically required. Encryption: TLS often used. Purpose: email system backbone.

questions.question: What does IMAP stand for?
questions.explanation: IMAP: email retrieval protocol. Port: 143, 993 typical. Advantage: mail stays on server. Synchronization: multiple devices. Advantage: better than POP3. Purpose: modern email access.

questions.question: What does SSH stand for?
questions.explanation: SSH: secure remote access protocol. Port: 22 standard. Authentication: keys or passwords. Encryption: all traffic encrypted. Uses: server administration. Security: widely considered safe.

questions.question: What does CDN stand for?
questions.explanation: CDN: distributed content servers. Purpose: faster delivery, load distribution. Technology: caches, optimization. Providers: CloudFlare, Akamai. Benefits: speeds up global access. Cost: improves user experience.

questions.question: What does IoT stand for?
questions.explanation: IoT: networked physical devices. Examples: smart homes, wearables, sensors. Connectivity: WiFi, cellular, Bluetooth. Security: often weak, concerns. Growth: rapidly expanding. Applications: endless possibilities.
